title: 112_hr1991
content: The "Cocopah Lands Act" may be cited as the short title. The findings section is included in the Act. The Cocopah Tribe of Arizona's reservation in Yuma County was established in 1917 by President Woodrow Wilson. The Tribe's land holdings consist of approximately 6,226.3 acres of trust land across 3 noncontiguous reservations. Additional lands were purchased to support housing, water, and economic development for tribal members. However, the current trust land base is insufficient to meet these needs. The Tribe acquired 7 parcels of land adjacent to their reservation between 1986 and 2005, which are now classified as "Tribal fee lands" under Federal law. The Cocopah Tribe of Arizona acquired parcels of land adjacent to their reservation between 1986 and 2005, now classified as "Tribal fee lands" under Federal law. These parcels cannot be taken into trust for gaming purposes. The best solution for the Tribe's land and economic needs is for the Secretary to take these lands in Yuma County into trust for the Tribe. The Act defines "Tribe" as the Cocopah Tribe of Arizona and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. The Act also specifies that certain lands in Yuma County should be taken into trust for the Tribe. The Cocopah Tribe of Arizona, as defined in the Act, can transfer land to the Secretary to be taken into trust if there are no environmental issues or legal claims. The described land includes specific parcels in Yuma County, Arizona. Specific parcels in Yuma County, Arizona include Parcel 2 (Sibley purchase 1986), Parcel 3 (McDaniel purchase 1993), Parcel 4 (Holland purchase 1997), and Parcel 5 (Holland purchase 1997). These parcels consist of various sections of land with specific boundaries and easements. The easterly 15 feet of the north 220 feet of the NW\1/4\ of the NE\1/4\ in Sec. 31, T. 16 S., R. 22 E., San Bernardino Base and Meridian, Yuma County, Arizona, north of the levee and Salinity Canal for irrigation purposes. Parcel 6 includes Lots 21, 24, and 25 in Sec. 29, and Lots 16 and 17 and the N\1/2\ of the SW\1/4\ of the SE\1/4\ in Sec. 30, T. 16 S., R. 22 E., San Bernardino Meridian, Yuma County, Arizona. Parcel 7 consists of a portion of the W\1/2\ of the SE\1/4\ in Sec. 30, T. 9 S., R. 23 W., Gila and Salt River Base and Meridian, Yuma County, Arizona, south and east of the East Main Canal. Land taken into trust for the Tribe's initial reservation in Yuma County, Arizona, shall not be used for gaming under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
